9.text:
London is situated in the South-East of England
in the Thames Valley.

15.text:
the capital of the UK has been an important
financial,

19.text:
educational and cultural center for hundreds
of years.

23.text:
Of the many gifts England has given to the
world,

26.text:
none has been greater than her language and
literature.

30.text:
And if ever there's a city that reads like
an epic saga, it's London.

37.text: The story of London began in the Bronze Age,

42.text:
but it didn't really get going until the Romans
withdrew in the 5th century.

48.text:
Growing into one of the great medieval trading
cities,

52.text: she truly came of age in the 11th century,

54.text:
when William the Conqueror built the Tower
of London,

57.text:
which was to become one of England's grimmest
prisons.

63.text: London is very easy to navigate around,

65.text: and is compact enough to explore on foot.

71.text: This world city is filled with iconic symbols,

74.text:
and one of the most easily recognizable is
Tower Bridge,

77.text:
an impressive reminder of London's rapid expansion
during the industrial revolution.

82.text:
Just upriver, at the 
Houses of Parliament,

88.text:
Big Ben's reassuring chimes peal across the
city every hour, on the hour.

98.text:
Buckingham Palace, perhaps the most famous
palace in the world,

102.text: is the official residence of Queen Elizabeth.

105.text:
It's a popular London attraction, offering
tours of staterooms and gardens.

111.text:
Nearby, Kensington Palace is open to the public
year-round.

117.text: The palace and gardens will be remembered

118.text: as the home of Princess Di and Prince Charles,

121.text:
and have recently undergone a multimillion-pound
refurbishment.

130.text:
Another legacy of England's monarchy are the
Royal Parks of London.

134.text:
They were once reserved as private hunting
grounds for the royal family,

137.text:
but nowadays they're open for everyone to
enjoy.

142.text:
There are eight Royal Parks, and many of them
are in central London,

147.text:
and close to royal palaces and other historic
monuments.

152.text:
Green Park and St. James's Park are right
next to

155.text:
Buckingham Palace, Admiralty Arch and The
Mall.

159.text:
Hyde Park is perhaps the most famous with
its man-made lake, The Serpentine,

165.text:
and on the other side, Kensington Gardens
is a beautiful open expanse

170.text: that stretches east towards Kensington Palace.

175.text:
The Albert Memorial is at the southern end
of Kensington Gardens,

178.text:
and the striking bronze statue looks towards
the Royal Albert Hall

183.text:
The hall is yet another reminder of Queen
Victoria's

186.text: great love for her husband, Prince Albert.

195.text:
Many of London's greatest stories have begun
in her houses of worship,

199.text:
and none is so impressive and important as
Westminster Abbey.

204.text:
This is where kings and queens have been crowned,
married and even buried.

212.text:
London was rebuilt after The Great Fire in
1666,

215.text:
and St. Paul's Cathedral is the most enduring
monument to the city's transformation.

221.text:
It's a great testament to British strength
and resilience.

232.text:
The West End in central London is a story
in itself.

236.text: Here the streets are lined with ancient buildings,

238.text:
but the throngs of people are out to have
fun.

242.text:
By day, the charming boutiques and cafés
hum with shoppers,

247.text:
and by night the bars along Carnaby Street
are packed

253.text:
This is one of the largest theater districts
in the world.

257.text:
And at times it can feel like you're on a
Monopoly board,

264.text:
with Coventry Street, Trafalgar Square and
Piccadilly Circus all close by.

269.text: Moving away from the historic center,

272.text:
London's trendy suburbs offer a different
kind of story.

276.text:
The Portobello Road Markets in Notting Hill
attract thousands of visitors,

280.text:
especially to the antiques markets that's
held on Saturdays,

283.text:
while the edgier Camden Town features six
popular markets

287.text: that are open every day of the week,

289.text:
and operate along her streets, the canal,
and in her historic stables.

296.text:
London is a city that honors not only her
own story,

303.text: but also the story of humankind.

305.text:
The British Museum is one of the finest in
the world,

308.text:
and her treasures cover thousands of years
of history and number in the millions.

313.text:
The museum is open every day, and best of
all, it's free.

318.text: From the ancient to the modern,

320.text:
The London Eye offers a complete change of
pace and perspective.

328.text: The massive wheel is over 400 feet high,

330.text: and takes 30 minutes to complete one rotation.

334.text: From here you can see the London of old,

337.text:
as well as some of the city's newest additions,
all in air-conditioned comfort.

349.text: London will always be a city that looks towards

351.text: the past and the future in equal measure.

357.text:
the fabric and the skyline of this city is
forever turning over a new page.

362.text:
Which is, after all, what every great story
should do.
